leanCodeSectionsTree.body:
User notes:
About this chapter: Chapter 12 provides minimum provisions for the interior of buildings—the occupied environment. Ventilation, lighting, and space heating are directly regulated in this chapter and in conjunction with the Mechanical Code of New York State and the Energy Conservation Construction Code of New York State. Minimum room size, maximum room-to-room sound transmission and classroom acoustics are set for educational occupancies.
Code development reminder: Code change proposals to sections preceded by the designation [P] will be considered by a code development committee meting during the 2024 (Group A) Code Development Cycle. All other code change proposals will be considered by a code development committee meeting during the 2025 (Group B) Code Development Cycle.

children.body: The provisions of this chapter shall govern ventilation, temperature control, lighting, yards and courts, sound transmission, enhanced classroom acoustics, interior space dimensions, access to unoccupied spaces, toilet and bathroom requirements and ultraviolet (UV) germicidal irradiation systems associated with the interior spaces of buildings.

diagrams.title: Reduced Ventilation of Attics
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The required net free ventilation area of attic spaces may be reduced from 1/150 to 1/300 of the area of the space being ventilated when both of the following conditions are met.

Condition 1: if the project is in climate zone 6, 7, or 8 a class I or class II vapor retarder must be installed on the interior (warm side in winter) side of the ceiling.

Condition 2: not less than 40% and up to 50% of the required ventilation area is provided by ventilators located within 3' vertical feet of the ridge or highest point of the space.

diagrams.title: Ventilation of Rafter Spaces with Ceilings Directly Attached
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where the ceiling is directly applied to the underside of roof rafters, cross ventilation of the rafter space is required. The rafter space ventilation openings are required to be protected from the entry of snow and rain. Where insulation is installed a 1" minimum clearance is required between the roof sheathing and the insulation. Blocking and bridging within the rafter spaces shall not block the free flow of air.

diagrams.title: Example: Ventilation of Attics - Conventional Attics
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Enclosed attics and rafter spaces enclosed by ceilings directly applied to rafters are required to have cross ventilation. The minimum amount of required ventilation is defined in the code.

diagrams.title: Example: Ventilation of Attics - Clg. Applied Directly to Roof Rafters
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Enclosed attics and rafter spaces enclosed by ceilings directly applied to rafters are required to have cross ventilation. The minimum amount of required ventilation is defined in the code.

Where the ceiling is applied directly to the underside of the roof rafters, each enclosed rafter space must be provided with the minimum required ventilation. The code requires a minimum net free ventilation area greater than or equal to 1/150th of the area being enclosed. The net free ventilation provided by a ventilation product is typically provided by the manufacturer of the ventilation product and is typically provided in square inches. It is important to make sure that units of the required ventilation and the provided ventilation are the same when checking calculations for compliance.

children.body:
Buildings shall be provided with natural ventilation in accordance with Section 1202.5, or mechanical ventilation in accordance with the Mechanical Code of New York State.
Dwelling units complying with the air leakage requirements of the Energy Conservation Construction Code of New York State or 2024 New York State ASHRAE 90.1 shall be ventilated by mechanical means in accordance with Section 403 of the Mechanical Code of New York State. Ambulatory care facilities and Group I-2 occupancies shall be ventilated by mechanical means in accordance with Section 407 of the Mechanical Code of New York State.
Roof assemblies shall be ventilated in accordance with this section or shall comply with Section 1202.3.

diagrams.title: Attic Ventilation
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Attic ventilation helps control the temperature and moisture content of the attic space. Provides benefits including allowing the interior space to be more easily cooled in the summer without the added heat load of the attic space which would continue to be present at night, even when the outside air is cooler. Also in cold climates, the warmer air of the attic contributes to the melting of snow and ice, which then refreezes on the eaves, creating an "ice dam" which damages the roofing and other parts of the home. Venting this heat helps reduce this damage.

diagrams.title: Attic and Floor Draftstopping
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Draftstop: A material, device or construction installed to restrict the movement of air within open spaces of concealed areas of building components such as crawl spaces, floor/ceiling assemblies, roof/ceiling assemblies and attics.

Attic draftstopping helps to slow the spread of fire (via restricting air movement, not flames) and smoke in the event of a fire. By blocking air movement between the living space and the attic or sections of attic, draftstopping can help to reduce the risk of fire spreading from the attic to other parts of the building through an open floor cavity. It can serve a few other important purposes:

  1. Energy Efficiency: Draftstopping could help to reduce the amount of air that moves in and out of the attic, which can help to reduce heating and cooling losses between individual units sharing an attic. This can result in lower energy bills and a more comfortable living environment.
  2. Improved Indoor Air Quality: Draftstopping can help to prevent outdoor pollutants and allergens from entering the living space through the attic. This can improve indoor air quality and reduce the risk of respiratory problems.
  3. Pest Prevention: Attic draftstopping can also help to prevent pests, such as rodents and insects, from entering the living spaces.

diagrams.title: Eave Baffles
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where air-permeable insulation is utilized to insulate the ceiling of a vented attic baffles are required to install continuously along vented soffits and eaves. The baffles are require to maintain the same or more vent area as provided at the eave or soffit between the insulation and roof deck. Each baffle is required to extend from the outside edge of the top plat to the top of the insulation.

children.body:
Enclosed attics and enclosed rafter spaces formed where ceilings are applied directly to the underside of roof framing members shall have cross ventilation for each separate space by ventilation openings protected against the entrance of rain and snow. Blocking and bridging shall be arranged so as not to interfere with the movement of air. An airspace of not less than 1 inch (25 mm) shall be provided between the insulation and the roof sheathing. The net free ventilating area shall be not less than 1/150 of the area of the space ventilated. Ventilators shall be installed in accordance with manufacturer's installation instructions.
Exception: The net free cross-ventilation area shall be permitted to be reduced to 1/300 provided both of the following conditions are met:
  1. In Climate Zones 6, 7 and 8, a Class I or II vapor retarder is installed on the warm-in-winter side of the ceiling.
  2. At least 40 percent and not more than 50 percent of the required venting area is provided by ventilators located in the upper portion of the attic or rafter space. Upper ventilators shall be located not more than 3 feet (914 mm) below the ridge or highest point of the space, measured vertically, with the balance of the ventilation provided by eave or cornice vents. Where the location of wall or roof framing members conflicts with the installation of upper ventilators, installation more than 3 feet (914 mm) below the ridge or highest point of the space shall be permitted.

diagrams.title: Reduced Ventilation of Attics
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The required net free ventilation area of attic spaces may be reduced from 1/150 to 1/300 of the area of the space being ventilated when both of the following conditions are met.

Condition 1: if the project is in climate zone 6, 7, or 8 a class I or class II vapor retarder must be installed on the interior (warm side in winter) side of the ceiling.

Condition 2: not less than 40% and up to 50% of the required ventilation area is provided by ventilators located within 3' vertical feet of the ridge or highest point of the space.

children.body: Exterior openings into the attic space of any building intended for human occupancy shall be protected to prevent the entry of birds, squirrels, rodents, snakes and other similar creatures. Openings for ventilation having a least dimension of not less than 1/16 inch (1.6 mm) and not more than 1/4 inch (6.4 mm) shall be permitted. Openings for ventilation having a least dimension larger than 1/4 inch (6.4 mm) shall be provided with corrosion-resistant wire cloth screening, hardware cloth, perforated vinyl or similar material with openings having a least dimension of not less than 1/16 inch (1.6 mm) and not more than 1/4 inch (6.4 mm). Where combustion air is obtained from an attic area, it shall be in accordance with Chapter 7 of the Mechanical Code of New York State.

Unvented attics and unvented enclosed roof framing assemblies created by ceilings applied directly to the underside of the roof framing members/rafters and the structural roof sheathing at the top of the roof framing members shall be permitted where all of the following conditions are met:
  1. The unvented attic space is completely within the building thermal envelope.
  2. No interior Class I vapor retarders are installed on the ceiling side (attic floor) of the unvented attic assembly or on the ceiling side of the unvented enclosed roof framing assembly.
  3. Where wood shingles or shakes are used, not less than a 1/4-inch (6.4 mm) vented airspace separates the shingles or shakes and the roofing underlayment above the structural sheathing.
  4. In Climate Zones 5, 6, 7 and 8, any air-impermeable insulation shall be a Class II vapor retarder or shall have a Class II vapor retarder coating or covering in direct contact with the underside of the insulation.
  5. Insulation shall comply with either Item 5.1 or 5.2, and additionally Item 5.3.
    1. Item 5.1.1, 5.1.2, 5.1.3 or 5.1.4 shall be met, depending on the air permeability of the insulation directly under the structural roof sheathing.
      1. Where only air-impermeable insulation is provided, it shall be applied in direct contact with the underside of the structural roof sheathing.
      2. Where air-permeable insulation is provided inside the building thermal envelope, it shall be installed in accordance with Item 5.1.1. In addition to the air-permeable insulation installed directly below the structural sheathing, rigid board or sheet insulation shall be installed directly above the structural roof sheathing in accordance with the R-value percentages in Table 1202.3 for condensation control.
      3. Where both air-impermeable and air-permeable insulation are provided, the air-impermeable insulation shall be applied in direct contact with the underside of the structural roof sheathing in accordance with Item 5.1.1 and shall be in accordance with the R-value percentages in Table 1202.3 for condensation control. The air-permeable insulation shall be installed directly under the air-impermeable insulation.
      4. Alternatively, sufficient rigid board or sheet insulation shall be installed directly above the structural roof sheathing to maintain the monthly average temperature of the underside of the structural roof sheathing above 45°F (7°C). For calculation purposes, an interior air temperature of 68°F (20°C) is assumed and the exterior air temperature is assumed to be the monthly average outside air temperature of the three coldest months.
    2. In Climate Zones 1, 2 and 3, air-permeable insulation installed in unvented attics shall meet the following requirements:
      1. A vapor diffusion port shall be installed not more than 12 inches (305 mm) from the highest point of the roof, measured vertically from the highest point of the roof to the lower edge of the port.
      2. The port area shall be greater than or equal to 1/150 of the ceiling area. Where there are multiple ports in the attic, the sum of the port areas shall be greater than or equal to the area requirement.
      3. The vapor permeable membrane in the vapor diffusion port shall have a vapor permeance rating of greater than or equal to 20 perms when tested in accordance with Procedure A of ASTM E96.
      4. The vapor diffusion port shall serve as an air barrier between the attic and the exterior of the building.
      5. The vapor diffusion port shall protect the attic against the entrance of rain and snow.
      6. Framing members and blocking shall not block the free flow of water vapor to the port. Not less than a 2-inch (50 mm) space shall be provided between any blocking and the roof sheathing. Air-permeable insulation shall be permitted within that space.
      7. The roof slope shall be greater than or equal to 3 units vertical in 12 units horizontal (3:12).
      8. Where only air-permeable insulation is used, it shall be installed directly below the structural roof sheathing, on top the attic floor, or on top of the ceiling.
      9. Where only air-permeable insulation is used and is installed directly below the structural roof sheathing, air shall be supplied at a flow rate greater than or equal to 50 cubic feet per minute (23.6 L/s) per 1,000 square feet (93 m2) of ceiling.
    3. The air shall be supplied from ductwork providing supply air to the occupiable space when the conditioning system is operating. Alternatively, the air shall be supplied by a supply fan when the conditioning system is operating. Where preformed insulation board is used as the air-impermeable insulation layer, it shall be sealed at the perimeter of each individual sheet interior surface to form a continuous layer.
Exceptions:
  1. Section 1202.3 does not apply to special use structures or enclosures such as swimming pool enclosures, data processing centers, hospitals or art galleries.
  2. Section 1202.3 does not apply to enclosures in Climate Zones 5 through 8 that are humidified beyond 35 percent during the three coldest months.
children.displayTitle: 1202.3 Unvented Attic and Unvented Enclosed Rafter Assemblies
children.titleText: Unvented Attic and Unvented Enclosed Rafter Assemblies

children.body: The space between the bottom of the floor joists and the earth under any building except spaces occupied by basements or cellars shall be provided with ventilation in accordance with Section 1202.4.1, 1202.4.2 or 1202.4.3.

diagrams.title: Under-Floor Ventilation
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section R408.1 defines the minimum amount of ventilation required to prevent water vapor escaping from the earth from damaging the structure. The aggregate amount of ventilation opening required is defined as 1 sf of net area per 150 sf of enclosed under-floor area. The ventilation opening area required may be reduced to 1 sf of net area per 1500 sf of enclosed under-floor area if a class 1 vapor retarder covering the underfloor ground surface is provided. To take advantage of the reduced ventilation requirements with a vapor retarder the openings are required to be arranged such that they provide cross ventilation of the enclosed under-floor space. The minimum ventilation opening arrangement and locations are also defined. Opening must be provided within 3' of each building corner.

diagrams.title: Example: Under-Floor Ventilation (Open Earth)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Residential code section R408.1 defines the minimum amount of ventilation required to prevent water vapor escaping from the earth from damaging the structure. Opening must be provided within 3' of each building corner essentially making 4 the minimum number of openings. The aggregate amount of ventilation opening required is defined as 1 sf of net area per 150 sf of enclosed under-floor area. The ventilation opening area required may be reduced to 1 sf of net area per 1500 sf of enclosed under-floor area if a class 1 vapor retarder covering the underfloor ground surface is provided. To take advantage of the reduced ventilation requirements with a vapor retarder the openings are required to be arranged such that they provide cross ventilation of the enclosed under-floor space.

Building code section 1202.4 defines the minimum amount of ventilation required to prevent water vapor escaping from the earth from damaging the structure. Cross ventilation is required making the minimum number of openings 2. The aggregate amount of ventilation opening required is defined as 1 sf of net area per 150 sf of enclosed under-floor area. The ventilation opening area required may be reduced to 1 sf of net area per 1500 sf of enclosed under-floor area if a class 1 vapor retarder covering the underfloor ground surface is provided.

children.body:
Ventilation openings through foundation walls shall be provided. The openings shall be placed so as to provide cross ventilation of the under-floor space. The net area of ventilation openings shall be in accordance with Section 1202.4.1.1 or 1202.4.1.2. Ventilation openings shall be covered for their height and width with any of the following materials, provided that the least dimension of the covering shall be not greater than 1/4 inch (6.4 mm):
  1. Perforated sheet metal plates not less than 0.070 inch (1.8 mm) thick.
  2. Expanded sheet metal plates not less than 0.047 inch (1.2 mm) thick.
  3. Cast-iron grilles or gratings.
  4. Extruded load-bearing vents.
  5. Hardware cloth of 0.035-inch (0.89 mm) wire or heavier.
  6. Corrosion-resistant wire mesh, with the least dimension not greater than 1/8 inch (3.2 mm).
  7. Operable louvres, where ventilation is provided in accordance with Section 1202.4.1.2.

children.body: The net area of ventilation openings for crawl spaces with uncovered earth floors shall be not less than 1 square foot for each 150 square feet (0.67 m2 for each 100 m2) of crawl space area.
children.displayTitle: 1202.4.1.1 Ventilation Area for Crawl Spaces With Open Earth Floors
children.titleText: Ventilation Area for Crawl Spaces With Open Earth Floors

children.body: The net area of ventilation openings for crawl spaces with the ground surface covered with a Class I vapor retarder shall be not less than 1 square foot for each 1,500 square feet (0.67 m2 for each 1000 m2) of crawl space area.

diagrams.title: Insulation: Residential Crawlspace Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In residences an uninsulated floor is allowed over a crawl space, provided the crawl space is unvented to the exterior, the crawl space walls are insulated and a Class I vapor retarder is placed over any areas of exposed earth. The vapor retarder joints shall have a 6" minimum lap and be sealed with tap. The perimeter of the vapor retarder needs to extend up an be attached to a stem wall. The insulation needs to extend from the bottom of the floor above the crawl space to grade and then horizontally or vertically for another 24". Required crawl space wall insulation R-value is driven by the site's climate zone as it applies to table R402.1.2. Verify with the listing of the product and/or the building or residential code if thermal protection is required for the insulation.

children.displayTitle: 1202.4.1.2 Ventilation Area for Crawl Spaces With Covered Floors
children.titleText: Ventilation Area for Crawl Spaces With Covered Floors

children.body: In extremely cold climates, where a ventilation opening will cause a detrimental loss of energy, ventilation openings to the interior of the structure shall be provided.
Mechanical ventilation shall be provided to crawl spaces where the ground surface is covered with a Class I vapor retarder. Ventilation shall be in accordance with Section 1202.4.3.1 or 1202.4.3.2.

Continuously operated mechanical ventilation shall be provided at a rate of 1.0 cubic foot per minute (cfm) for each 50 square feet (1.02 L/s for each 10 m2) of crawl space ground surface area and the ground surface shall be covered with a Class I vapor retarder.

The crawl space shall be conditioned in accordance with the Mechanical Code of New York State and the walls of the crawl space shall be insulated in accordance with the Energy Conservation Construction Code of New York State.

For buildings in flood hazard areas as established in Section 1612.3, the openings for under-floor ventilation shall be deemed as meeting the flood opening requirements of ASCE 24 provided that the ventilation openings are designed and installed in accordance with ASCE 24.

diagrams.title: Enclosures with Flood Openings: Zone A
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Requirements of construction in floodplains are found in FEMA Technical Bulletins, the Code of Federal Regulations, Local Floodplain Ordinances and the Building Codes. Local jurisdictions may require more stringent requirements than the building code or federal regulations in order to qualify for lower flood insurance rates.

Enclosures below the lowest floor, including parking or storage areas or require vents to allow the equalization of hydrostatic forces so that the walls or foundation are not compromised by flood waters. Source: fema.gov

diagrams.title: Below Grade Crawlspaces in Zone A (FEMA)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
While communities may now allow below-grade crawlspace construction in the Special Flood Hazard Area, this type of construction is not the recommended construction method, because of the increased likelihood of problems with water accumulation, moisture damage, and drainage. The use of crawlspace construction with the interior grade at or above the lowest adjacent grade minimizes the occurrence of these problems. Verify with your local floodplain administrator if the below grade crawlspaces are permitted in your jurisdiction and if any drainage requirements exist, if used.
See FEMA Technical Bulletin 11 for more information

diagrams.title: Flood: Wet Floodproofing Garages, Crawlspaces
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Flooding of a structure's interior is intended to counteract hydrostatic pressure on the walls, surfaces, and supports of the structure by equalizing interior with exterior water levels during a flood. Inundation also reduces the danger of buoyancy from hydrostatic uplift forces. Wet measures may require alteration of a structure's design and construction, use of flood-resistant materials, adjustment of allowed in only building operation and maintenance procedures, relocation and treatment of equipment and contents, and emergency preparedness for actions that require human intervention.
Source: FEMA Technical Bulletin TB 7-93, fema.gov

diagrams.title: Flood Venting Layout
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Every enclosed area is required to have at least two flood openings on exterior walls. Flood openings should be installed in at least two sides of each enclosed area to decrease the chance that all openings will be blocked by floating debris and to allow for more even filling and drainage of enclosed areas than if openings are installed on only one side. FEMA recommends that openings be distributed around the perimeter of enclosed areas unless there is clear justification for putting all of the openings on only one or two sides, such as in townhouses with limited exterior walls and buildings set into sloping sites. If openings are not distributed around the perimeter, an imbalance in flood loads could result in damage to or collapse of walls.

The illustration shows a foundation plan with multiple enclosures and openings in the perimeter wall of each enclosed area. Note that the number of openings shown is for illustration purposes only; the total number of openings and the adequacy of the net open area of the openings depend on the type of opening and whether air-vent devices or engineered openings are installed.

In some situations, openings in interior walls or partitions are necessary to ensure that floodwater can reach all enclosed areas and minimize unbalanced hydrostatic loads on interior and exterior walls. When openings are used in interior walls, the total number of openings and their net open area should be based on the size of the enclosed area, but openings in interior walls are not counted toward the required total opening requirement based on the exterior measurement of the enclosed area. To maintain safe fire separation, flood openings should not be placed in the wall separating a garage from living spaces and crawlspaces unless devices used as flood openings that are designed to satisfy fire-separation requirements are used.

Source: FEMA Technical Bulletin 1, March 2020 www.fema.gov

children.body: Natural ventilation of an occupied space shall be through windows, doors, louvers or other openings to the outdoors. The operating mechanism for such openings shall be provided with ready access so that the openings are readily controllable by the building occupants.

diagrams.title: Habitable Space: Light / Ventilation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Per the Residential Code, Habitable Space is a space in a building for living, sleeping, eating or cooking. Bathrooms, toilet rooms, closets, halls, storage or utility spaces and similar areas are not considered habitable spaces.

Natural lighting and ventilation requirements are found in both the Residential and Building Codes. While both codes require 8% / 4% of the room area for light and ventilation, a difference exists regarding light and ventilation requirements from adjoining rooms (10% for Residential Code, vs. 8% for the Building Code.)

diagrams.title: Window Fall Protection
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Window fall protection is a safety measure implemented to prevent accidents and injuries, especially for children, due to falls from windows. It typically involves installing devices like window guards, safety nets, window stops, or window-opening control devices that restrict the extent a window can be opened, making it difficult to accidentally fall through the window.

Installation of window fall protection measures ensures that the occupants of a building remain safe from potential accidents. These safety measures are especially crucial in multi-story buildings, where the risk of severe injury or fatalities due to window falls is higher.

diagrams.title: Location of Vent Terminal (IPC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Vent terminals should be kept a minimum distance away from openings or air intake openings to prevent sewer gases from entering the building. Verify with the local jurisdiction about the required extension of the vent terminal above the roof.

children.body: The openable area of the openings to the outdoors shall be not less than 4 percent of the floor area being ventilated.

Where rooms and spaces without openings to the outdoors are ventilated through an adjoining room, the opening to the adjoining room shall be unobstructed and shall have an area of not less than 8 percent of the floor area of the interior room or space, but not less than 25 square feet (2.3 m2). The openable area of the openings to the outdoors shall be based on the total floor area being ventilated.
Exception: Exterior openings required for ventilation shall be allowed to open into a sunroom with thermal isolation or a patio cover provided that the openable area between the sunroom addition or patio cover and the interior room shall have an area of not less than 8 percent of the floor area of the interior room or space, but not less than 20 square feet (1.86 m2). The openable area of the openings to the outdoors shall be based on the total floor area being ventilated.

diagrams.title: Habitable Space: Light / Ventilation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Per the Residential Code, Habitable Space is a space in a building for living, sleeping, eating or cooking. Bathrooms, toilet rooms, closets, halls, storage or utility spaces and similar areas are not considered habitable spaces.

Natural lighting and ventilation requirements are found in both the Residential and Building Codes. While both codes require 8% / 4% of the room area for light and ventilation, a difference exists regarding light and ventilation requirements from adjoining rooms (10% for Residential Code, vs. 8% for the Building Code.)

children.body: Where openings below grade provide required natural ventilation, the outside horizontal clear space measured perpendicular to the opening shall be one and one-half times the depth of the opening. The depth of the opening shall be measured from the average adjoining ground level to the bottom of the opening.

diagrams.title: Natural Ventilation Openings Below Grade (IMC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In the Mechanical Code, natural ventilation for areas below grade does not have the advantage of breezes or the direct natural flow of air at the ground level. Therefore, a larger opening of the window well is required to provide the air needed. Where below grade windows are also used as emergency escape openings, window wells shall comply with the more restrictive of natural ventilation or minimum window well sizes for emergency escape windows.

children.body: Contaminant sources in naturally ventilated spaces shall be removed in accordance with the Mechanical Code of New York State and the Fire Code of New York State.
Rooms containing bathtubs, showers, spas and similar bathing fixtures shall be mechanically ventilated in accordance with the Mechanical Code of New York State.
Where natural ventilation is to be provided by openings onto yards or courts, such yards or courts shall comply with Section 1205.

Ventilation and exhaust systems for occupancies and operations involving flammable or combustible hazards or other contaminant sources as covered in the Mechanical Code of New York State or the Fire Code of New York State shall be provided as required by both codes.

Interior spaces intended for human occupancy shall be provided with active or passive space heating systems capable of maintaining an indoor temperature of not less than 68°F (20°C) at a point 3 feet (914 mm) above the floor on the design heating day.
Exceptions: Space heating systems are not required for:
  1. Interior spaces where the primary purpose of the space is not associated with human comfort.
  2. Group F, H, S or U occupancies.

diagrams.title: Artificial Light
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where natural lighting is not provided in spaces intended for human occupancy artificial lighting is required. The artificial light is required to achieve an average illumination level of 10 footcandles on an imaginary plane 30" above the entire floor of the space.

children.body: Every space intended for human occupancy shall be provided with natural light by means of exterior glazed openings in accordance with Section 1204.2 or shall be provided with artificial light in accordance with Section 1204.3. Exterior glazed openings shall open directly onto a public way or onto a yard or court in accordance with Section 1205.
The minimum net glazed area shall be not less than 8 percent of the floor area of the room served.

For the purpose of natural lighting, any room is permitted to be considered as a portion of an adjoining room where one-half of the area of the common wall is open and unobstructed and provides an opening of not less than one-tenth of the floor area of the interior room or 25 square feet (2.32 m2), whichever is greater.
Exception: Openings required for natural light shall be permitted to open into a sunroom with thermal isolation or a patio cover where the common wall provides a glazed area of not less than one-tenth of the floor area of the interior room or 20 square feet (1.86 m2), whichever is greater.

Exterior openings required by Section 1204.2 for natural light shall open directly onto a public way, yard or court, as set forth in Section 1205.
Exceptions:
  1. Required exterior openings are permitted to open into a roofed porch where the porch meets all of the following criteria:
    1. Abuts a public way, yard or court.
    2. Has a ceiling height of not less than 7 feet (2134 mm).
    3. Has a longer side at least 65 percent open and unobstructed.
  2. Skylights are not required to open directly onto a public way, yard or court.
Artificial light shall be provided that is adequate to provide an average illumination of 10 footcandles (107 lux) over the area of the room at a height of 30 inches (762 mm) above the floor level.

diagrams.title: Artificial Light
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where natural lighting is not provided in spaces intended for human occupancy artificial lighting is required. The artificial light is required to achieve an average illumination level of 10 footcandles on an imaginary plane 30" above the entire floor of the space.

diagrams.title: Bathroom Light and Ventilation - Exception
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Natural light and ventilation is required in bathrooms and is typically provided by a operable window. Mechanical ventilation of bathrooms is required by the plumbing code by reference to the mechanical code (Table 403.3.2.3) and is typically provided by an exhaust fan. Providing natural light and ventilation may be omitted provided sufficient artificial light and mechanical ventilation, typically and exhaust fan, is provided. The level of artificial light required must provide an average of 10 fc at a plane 30" above the floor. The exhaust fan must be able to provide 50 cfm if intermittent (switched, humidistat, timer controlled) or 20 cfm if continuously operated. The duct from the exhaust fan must expel air directly to the exterior of the building, not attics or crawl or other spaces within the building envelope.

diagrams.title: Lighting Outlets - Guest Rooms / Suites
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The electrical code provides specific requirements, and exceptions, for guest rooms, which are generally Group R-1 occupancy, for transient individuals.

children.body: Stairways within dwelling units and exterior stairways serving a dwelling unit shall have an illumination level on tread runs of not less than 1 footcandle (11 lux). Stairways in other occupancies shall be governed by Chapter 10.

diagrams.title: Exterior Stair Illumination (RC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stairways require an illumination source to be used safely. Stairways to a basement would be those meeting the rise/run and other requirements of the stairway. Illumination would not be required at stairs covered by hinged bulkhead doors, where the height from the basement finished floor level to grade adjacent to the stairway is not more than 8 feet, per Section R311.7.10.2.

diagrams.title: Interior Stair Illumination (RC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
A foot-candle (fc) is a unit of illuminance, representing the amount of light that falls onto a surface. It is defined as one lumen per square foot. To visualize what one foot-candle of illuminance looks like, consider the following description:

Imagine a single candle lit in a completely dark room. If you were to measure the light falling on a one-square-foot surface situated one foot away from the candle (in direct line with the flame and without any obstructions), that would be approximately equivalent to one foot-candle of illuminance.

In practical terms, this is a rather low level of light, akin to the soft, dim light you might experience in a room illuminated only by candlelight. It's more than enough to make out shapes and some details, but it's much dimmer than the lighting levels we're used to in well-lit indoor spaces. To put it into perspective, a typical home living room in the evening with artificial light might range from 10 to 50 foot-candles, whereas an office lighting is typically brighter, often around 30 to 50 foot-candles.

diagrams.title: Stair Illumination Level for Accessibility
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stairs are required to achieve an illumination level of 1 foot-candle measured at the center of each tread. The first 24" of each landing adjacent to the top or bottom riser stair nosing is required to achieve an illumination level of 1 foot-candle. When in use the same to areas are required to achieve and illumination level of 10 foot-candles. Lighting may be controlled by manual switches top and bottom that enable a disabled user to turn the lighting level up prior to departing the landing for the stair run or via motion sensing lighting switches. Motion sensing controls need to provide fail-safe operation, be activated by occupancy of the stairway or landings, and keep the lights on for a duration of 15 minutes minimum upon each activation. If automatic controls are provided they must be able to turn on the lights for the stairway and its associated landings prior to a step being used.

children.body: The control for activation of the required stairway lighting shall be in accordance with NFPA 70.
The means of egress shall be illuminated in accordance with Section 1008.1.

diagrams.title: Occupant Loads: Outdoor Areas
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1004.7 is to ensure that Outdoor Areas have adequate means for emergency evacuation. It gives the building official the authority to determine the occupant load for outdoor areas. It establishes that the Means of Egress for Outdoor Areas be established per the requirements of Chapter 10 of the building code, the same requirements as any other room or space. It provides exceptions for outdoor areas used exclusively for servicing the building and outdoor areas serving R-3 buildings and R-2 dwelling units.

diagrams.title: Yards for Light and Ventilation
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1205 is to ensure that yards required to provide rooms with light and air are of adequate size. The code defines the minimum required yard width. 3' minimum is required for lightwells 2 stories or less in height. For lightwells from 3 to 14 stories the required width (W) needs to be increased by 1' for each story greater than 2 (W = 3' + (H-2)'. The required yard width for Lightwells over 14 stories tall are to be calculated as though the lightwell is 14 stories tall (W = 3'+(14-2)' = 15').

children.body: This section shall apply to yards and courts adjacent to exterior openings that provide natural light or ventilation. Such yards and courts shall be on the same lot as the building.

Yards shall be not less than 3 feet (914 mm) in width for buildings two stories or less above grade plane. For buildings more than two stories above grade plane, the minimum width of the yard shall be increased at the rate of 1 foot (305 mm) for each additional story. For buildings exceeding 14 stories above grade plane, the required width of the yard shall be computed on the basis of 14 stories above grade plane.

diagrams.title: Yards for Light and Ventilation
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1205 is to ensure that yards required to provide rooms with light and air are of adequate size. The code defines the minimum required yard width. 3' minimum is required for lightwells 2 stories or less in height. For lightwells from 3 to 14 stories the required width (W) needs to be increased by 1' for each story greater than 2 (W = 3' + (H-2)'. The required yard width for Lightwells over 14 stories tall are to be calculated as though the lightwell is 14 stories tall (W = 3'+(14-2)' = 15').

diagrams.title: Grade Plane
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines Grade Plane as a reference plane representing the average of finished ground level adjoining the building at exterior walls. Where the finished ground level slopes away from the exterior walls, the reference plane shall be established by the lowest points within the area between the building and the lot line or, where the lot line is more than 6 feet from the building, between the building and a point 6 feet from the building.

Grade plane is an imaginary horizontal reference plane that vertical measurements for a building are based on. It represents the average of the finished ground level adjoining the building at all exterior walls. On sloping sites, the grade plane will often fall between finish floor levels, and the determination on whether a story is a basement is determined by this. Special attention should be paid to portions of building where the grade slopes away from the building, due to the requirement to use a point 6 feet away from the building (or the lot line, if closer) in those conditions.

children.body: Courts shall be not less than 3 feet (914 mm) in width. Courts having windows opening on opposite sides shall be not less than 6 feet (1829 mm) in width. Courts shall be not less than 10 feet (3048 mm) in length unless bounded on one end by a public way or yard. For buildings more than two stories above grade plane, the court shall be increased 1 foot (305 mm) in width and 2 feet (610 mm) in length for each additional story. For buildings exceeding 14 stories above grade plane, the required dimensions shall be computed on the basis of 14 stories above grade plane.
Access shall be provided to the bottom of courts for cleaning purposes.

Courts more than two stories in height shall be provided with a horizontal air intake at the bottom not less than 10 square feet (0.93 m2) in area and leading to the exterior of the building unless abutting a yard or public way.
The bottom of every court shall be properly graded and drained to a public sewer or other approved disposal system complying with the Plumbing Code of New York State.

This section shall apply to common interior walls, partitions and floor/ceiling assemblies between adjacent dwelling units and sleeping units or between dwelling units and sleeping units and adjacent public areas.

Walls, partitions and floor-ceiling assemblies separating dwelling units and sleeping units from each other or from public or service areas shall have a sound transmission class of not less than 50 where tested in accordance with ASTM E90, or have a Normalized Noise Isolation Class (NNIC) rating of not less than 45 if field tested, in accordance with ASTM E336 for airborne noise. Alternatively, the sound transmission class of walls, partitions and floor-ceiling assemblies shall be established by engineering analysis based on a comparison of walls, partitions and floor-ceiling assemblies having sound transmission class ratings as determined by the test procedures set forth in ASTM E90. Engineering analysis shall be performed by a registered design professional. Penetrations or openings in construction assemblies for piping; electrical devices; recessed cabinets; bathtubs; soffits; or heating, ventilating or exhaust ducts shall be sealed, lined, insulated or otherwise treated to maintain the required ratings. This requirement shall not apply to entrance doors; however, such doors shall be tight fitting to the frame and sill.

diagrams.title: Airborne Sound Transmission (2021)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Sound travels either through air as a medium or through vibrations due to impacts or vibrations of an assembly due to the sound waves themselves. In order to reduce the airborne transmission of sound through an assembly, locations through which air can pass need to be appropriately constructed in a way to reduce the passage of air. Those parts of the assembly used to reduce sound transmission must also comply with the provisions of Section 720 when also a part of fire-resistive construction.

diagrams.title: Townhouse Common Walls at Roof
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Townhouse: A single-family dwelling unit constructed in a group of three or more attached units in which each unit extends from foundation to roof and with a yard or public way on not less than two sides.

Walls separating townhomes must meet more stringent fire rating requirements in order to protect adjacent dwellings. A two hour rated wall is required, unless a sprinkler system meeting requirements of NFPA 13D or an equivalent approved system. In that case, a one-hour rated wall may be allowed. Although not required by the Residential Code, designers should consider wall assemblies with an STC rating of at least 50 (See Building Code Section 1206.2).

diagrams.title: Two-Family Dwelling Separation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Dwelling Unit: A single unit providing complete independent living facilities for one or more persons, including permanent provisions for living, sleeping, eating, cooking and sanitation.

Draft Stop: A material, device or construction installed to restrict the movement of air within open spaces of concealed areas of building components such as crawl spaces, floor-ceiling assemblies, roof-ceiling assemblies and attics.

Two dwelling units can be structures known as "duplexes" or ADU's (Accessory Dwelling Units in some jurisdictions. When altering an existing residence to create a second unit, attention should be paid to the continuity of the dwelling separation between the existing dwelling and the new dwelling. This could require unexpected work to be required in the crawlspace (if present) or in the attic.

In certain jurisdictions, two family dwellings may be governed by either the Building Code or Residential Code (but provisions may not be mixed). In the Building Code, similar wall and floor separations are known as Fire Partitions (Section 708) and Horizontal Assemblies (Section 711). See also Section 420 for additional building code requirements.

diagrams.title: Airborne Sound Transmission
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Sound travels either through air as a medium or through vibrations due to impacts or vibrations of an assembly due to the sound waves themselves. In order to reduce the airborne transmission of sound through an assembly, locations through which air can pass need to be appropriately constructed in a way to reduce the passage of air. Those parts of the assembly used to reduce sound transmission must also comply with the provisions of Section 720 when also a part of fire-resistive construction.

children.body: The sound transmission class of concrete masonry and clay masonry assemblies shall be calculated in accordance with TMS 302 or determined through testing in accordance with ASTM E90.

Floor-ceiling assemblies between dwelling units and sleeping units or between a dwelling unit or sleeping unit and a public or service area within the structure shall have an impact insulation class rating of not less than 50 where tested in accordance with ASTM E492, or have a Normalized Impact Sound Rating (NISR) of not less than 45 if field tested in accordance with ASTM E1007. Alternatively, the impact insulation class of floor-ceiling assemblies shall be established by engineering analysis based on a comparison of floor-ceiling assemblies having impact insulation class ratings as determined by the test procedures in ASTM E492. Engineering analysis shall be performed by a registered design professional.

diagrams.title: Structure-Borne Sound
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Structure borne sound is sound transferred through the assembly by the impact or vibration of the actual phyisical materials. Some methods to reduce this sound transmission includes sound reducing mats between the flooring and the substrate on top of the floor. Also, the use of resilient light gauge metal channels on the bottom of joists can also help reduce transmission of structure borne sound.

children.displayTitle: [NY] Section 1207 Enhanced Classroom AcousticsReserved

children.body: Habitable spaces, other than a kitchen, shall be not less than 7 feet (2134 mm) in any plan dimension. Kitchens shall have a clear passageway of not less than 3 feet (914 mm) between counter fronts and appliances or counter fronts and walls.

diagrams.title: Habitable Space: Light / Ventilation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Per the Residential Code, Habitable Space is a space in a building for living, sleeping, eating or cooking. Bathrooms, toilet rooms, closets, halls, storage or utility spaces and similar areas are not considered habitable spaces.

Natural lighting and ventilation requirements are found in both the Residential and Building Codes. While both codes require 8% / 4% of the room area for light and ventilation, a difference exists regarding light and ventilation requirements from adjoining rooms (10% for Residential Code, vs. 8% for the Building Code.)

diagrams.title: Accessible Units: U-Kitchens
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Accessible, Type A and Type B dwelling units with U-shaped Kitchens shall provide a 60" clearance between all opposing cabinets, counter tops, appliances or walls. If elements are not placed on all three contiguous sides, the clearance between elements can be 40" in Type A and B units. Type C units must have a 40" min clearance between all opposing elements in either configuration. Clear floor space must be provided for fixtures and appliances as shown. State and local codes and regulations should be consulted. In addition, if a project scoping falls under the scoping of both the FHA and ADA Standards, the most restrictive of both sets of regulations apply, per DOJ / HUD Joint statement and the Advisory 224.1, in addition to state and local regulations.

diagrams.title: Pass-Through Kitchens: Countertop Clearances
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Per the FHA Design Manual: "The Guidelines require a clearance of at least 40 inches between all opposing base cabinets, countertops, appliances, and walls. The 40-inch clearance is measured from any countertop or the face of any appliance (excluding handles and controls) that projects into the kitchen to the opposing cabinet, countertop, appliance, or wall. Refrigerators vary greatly in depth and may extend up to eight inches beyond cabinet faces. Standard free-standing and drop-in ranges may project up to three inches. Appliance depths (excluding door handles) must be included when calculating the 40-inch clearances."

State and local codes and regulations should be consulted. In addition, if a project scoping falls under the scoping of both the FHA and ADA Standards, the most restrictive of both sets of regulations apply, per DOJ / HUD Joint statement and the Advisory 224.1, in addition to state and local regulations.

children.body:
Occupiable spaces, habitable spaces and corridors shall have a ceiling height of not less than 7 feet 6 inches (2286 mm) above the finished floor. Bathrooms, toilet rooms, kitchens, storage rooms and laundry rooms shall have a ceiling height of not less than 7 feet (2134 mm) above the finished floor.
Exceptions:
  1. In one- and two-family dwellings, beams or girders spaced not less than 4 feet (1219 mm) on center shall be permitted to project not more than 6 inches (152 mm) below the required ceiling height.
  2. If any room in a building has a sloped ceiling, the prescribed ceiling height for the room is required in one-half the area thereof. Any portion of the room measuring less than 5 feet (1524 mm) from the finished floor to the ceiling shall not be included in any computation of the minimum area thereof.
  3. The height of mezzanines and spaces below mezzanines shall be in accordance with Section 505.2.
  4. Corridors contained within a dwelling unit or sleeping unit in a Group R occupancy shall have a ceiling height of not less than 7 feet (2134 mm) above the finished floor.

diagrams.title: Electrical Panel - Work Space Height
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Electrical panels shall be provided with a clear work space of 36" by 30" minimum from the floor up to a height of 6'-6". However, In existing dwelling units where the electrical service panel is less than 200 amperes, the height of the working space is allowed to be less than 6'-6".

diagrams.title: Min. Means of Egress Ceiling Heights
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Provisions for minimum ceiling heights include the minimum allowed heights to ceilings, protrusions, headers and other structural elements and mechanical or plumbing systems including fire sprinklers. The provisions provide allowances in dwelling units for the provision of space for ventilation in corridors (by use of a reduced ceiling height) or the condition where a room walls include the sloping roof, which reduces the ceiling height in a portion of the room. There are exceptions in the existing building code where pre-existing non-conforming ceiling heights may be allowed to remain.

diagrams.title: Res. Fixture Clearances (IPC vs. UPC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fixture clearances shown apply to non-accessible / ADA conditions. Verify with multifamily housing or accessible fixture clearance requirements when fixtures are required to be accessible.

children.body: Any room with a furred ceiling shall be required to have the minimum ceiling height in two-thirds of the area thereof, but in no case shall the height of the furred ceiling be less than 7 feet (2134 mm).
Dwelling units shall have a minimum of 190 square feet (17.7 m2) of habitable space.

Every dwelling unit shall have not less than one room that shall have not less than 120 square feet (11.2 m2) of net floor area. Sleeping units and other habitable rooms of a dwelling unit shall have a net floor area of not less than 70 square feet (6.5 m2).
Exception: Kitchens are not required to be of a minimum floor area.

diagrams.title: Habitable Space: Light / Ventilation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Per the Residential Code, Habitable Space is a space in a building for living, sleeping, eating or cooking. Bathrooms, toilet rooms, closets, halls, storage or utility spaces and similar areas are not considered habitable spaces.

Natural lighting and ventilation requirements are found in both the Residential and Building Codes. While both codes require 8% / 4% of the room area for light and ventilation, a difference exists regarding light and ventilation requirements from adjoining rooms (10% for Residential Code, vs. 8% for the Building Code.)

diagrams.title: Gross vs. Net Area
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
BUILDING CODE DEFINITION
Floor Area, Gross: The floor area within the inside perimeter of the exterior walls of the building under consideration, exclusive of vent shafts and courts, without deduction for corridors, stairways, ramps, closets, the thickness of interior walls, columns or other features. The floor area of a building, or portion thereof, not provided with surrounding exterior walls shall be the usable area under the horizontal projection of the roof or floor above. The gross floor area shall not include shafts with no openings or interior courts.

Area, Building: The area included within surrounding exterior walls, or exterior walls and fire walls, exclusive of vent shafts and courts. Areas of the building not provided with surrounding walls shall be included in the building area if such areas are included within the horizontal projection of the roof or floor above.

Floor Area, Net: The actual occupied area not including unoccupied accessory areas such as corridors, stairways, ramps, toilet rooms, mechanical rooms and closets.

The 2014 NYC Building Code further explicitly excludes wall thicknesses, columns, fixed cabinets, equipment and furred-in spaces. Other codes do not explicitly address these items in the definition of Net Floor Area.

NFPA 1 and NFPA 101 DEFINITION
Gross Floor Area: The floor area within the inside perimeter of the outside walls of the building under consideration with no deduction for hallways, stairs, closets, thickness of interior walls, columns, elevator and building services shafts, or other features, but excluding floor openings associated with atriums and communicating spaces.

Net Floor Area: The floor area within the inside perimeter of the outside walls, or the outside walls and fire walls of the building, or outside and/or inside walls that bound an occupancy or incidental use area requiring the occupant load to be calculated using net floor area under consideration with deductions for hallways, stairs, closets, thickness of interior walls, columns, or other features.

Both Gross and Net area is used for occupant load calculations depending the function of the space chosen in Table 1004.5. Although effectively the same, the Building Area used for allowable building area calculations found in Chapter 5 has a unique definition, "Area, Building", in Chapter 2.

Net floor areas are also used for specific items, such as minimum required areas of dwelling unit spaces, calculation of refuge areas for horizontal exits, and calculation of occupant load factors related to determining the Risk Category in Chapter 16 when gross areas would normally be required. Also, keep in mind that local zoning / planning floor area calculations, as well as height calculations may substantially differ from the building code.

children.body:
Efficiency dwelling units shall conform to the requirements of the code except as modified herein:
  1. The unit's habitable space shall comply with Sections 1208.1 through 1208.4.
  2. The unit shall be provided with a separate closet.
  3. For other than Accessible, Type A and Type B dwelling units, the unit shall be provided with a kitchen sink, cooking appliance and refrigerator, each having a clear working space of not less than 30 inches (762 mm) in front. Light and ventilation conforming to this code shall be provided.
  4. The unit shall be provided with a separate bathroom containing a water closet, lavatory and bathtub or shower.

diagrams.title: Electrical Equipment with Limited Access
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 110.26 of the electrical code is to ensure that electrical equipment installed in locations with limited access may be safely serviced. The section only applies to equipment of 1000 volts or less to ground that require adjustment, or maintenance while energized. The section establishes the minimum opening size required to access the equipment service workspace and the required size of the workspace. Where Equipment workspace access is through a lay in ceiling the opening may not be smaller than 22 inches by 22 inches. Where equipment workspace access is through a floor the opening may not be smaller than 22 inches by 30 inches. Note that the 22x22 is for a lay in ceiling, and not an attic space. Building codes require a 22x30 opening, similar to "crawl space" as discussed in the electrical code.

The minimum size of the workspace width is the greater of 30 inches or the width of the equipment. The minimum depth or space in front of the equipment is established in Table 110.26(A)(1). The minimum height of the workspace in front of the equipment is the height required to install the equipment from within the limited space. Any access panels that are part of the equipment enclosure are required to be able to be opened at least 90 degrees into the work area. Access openings and ceiling structural members may overlap the required workspace area.

children.body: Crawl spaces shall be provided with not less than one access opening that shall be not less than 18 inches by 24 inches (457 mm by 610 mm).

An opening not less than 20 inches by 30 inches (559 mm by 762 mm) shall be provided to any attic area having a clear height of over 30 inches (762 mm). Clear headroom of not less than 30 inches (762 mm) shall be provided in the attic space at or above the access opening.

diagrams.title: Attic Access
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Attic access to areas of sufficient height or area are required to provide access for service of mechanical equipment, insulation or other uses of the attic. Attic access can be provided within the unit. Attic access would need to be provided on each side of a draft stop or wall extension provided due to a two-family dwelling condition. The Building Code and Residential Codes (2018) have two different requirements that dictate whether attic access is required, and two different measurements for the opening size.

children.body: Access to mechanical appliances installed in under-floor areas, in attic spaces and on roofs or elevated structures shall be in accordance with the Mechanical Code of New York State.

diagrams.title: Building Subdrains to Sumps
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Building Subdrain: That portion of a drainage system that does not drain by gravity into the building sewer. Building drainage that can't be naturally discharged to the sewer due to a lack of gravity flow has to be discharged into a suitably covered and vented sump. From this point, the accumulated liquid has to be automatically lifted and conveyed into the building's gravity drainage system or removed through other approved means. This might occur in a building with basement levels where the plumbing fixtures are installed below the level of the building sewer and public sewer or in areas of the building that are lower than the main drainage system, such as a sunken bathtub or a bathroom installed in a basement, making gravity drainage impossible.

Of note, the electrical code does not require a single receptacle supplying a permanently installed sump pump to have ground-fault circuit-interrupter (GFCI) protection if permanently wired in the 2020 code version. Older electrical codes don't require GFCI if the pump is permanently installed, but makes no mention of requiring permanent wiring. Verify the applicable year for your jurisdiction to ensure code compliant electrical installation of sump pumps.

diagrams.title: Ambulatory and Wheelchair Accessible Water Closets
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Ambulatory accessible toilet compartments provide parallel grab bars and benefit people who use crutches, canes, walkers and similar devices or who need support in sitting or standing. They do not accommodate wheelchairs or scooters and are required in addition to the wheelchair accessible compartment in toilet rooms with six or more toilet compartments or where the combined total of toilets and urinals is six or more. They are sized so that both grab bars are within reach. Grab bars must meet specifications for size, location, and securement.

diagrams.title: Single Toilet Room: ADA vs. A117.1 2017
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Significant differences exist between the ADA requirements for single toilet rooms and the A117.1-2017 Accessibility Code.

diagrams.title: Single Toilet Room: ADA vs. A117.1-2009
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Significant differences exist between the ADA requirements for single toilet rooms and the A117.1-2009 Accessibility Code.

diagrams.title: Walls and Partitions in Bathrooms and Toilet Rooms
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Walls within 2' of toilets, urinals and lavatories are required to be finished in a smooth, hard, nonabsorbent surface to 48" minimum above the finished flooring. Shower enclosure walls and walls above tubs with a shower head are required to have a smooth nonabsorbent finish to a height not less than 72" above the drain inlet.

diagrams.title: Luminaires in Bathtub and Shower Areas
Registers, Grilles and Diffusers - Prohibited Locations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Duct systems are required to provide volume dampers for balancing of the system. The volume dampers are required at each branch duct or at each register, grill or diffuser. All volume dampers required to balance the system must be able to be accessed. In toilet and bathing rooms, registers, grilles and diffusers are not allowed in the floors, the flooring base, or on walls within both 48" of the floor and 24" of a fixture. Floor registers need to be able to resist a 200 lb force applied to a 2" diameter disk applied at the registers weakest location.

diagrams.title: Bathtubs and Showers: Surfaces and Joints
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Shower enclosure wall surfaces are required to be both smooth and nonabsorbent. The smooth nonabsorbent wall surfaces must extend to a height that is 72" minimum above the shower drain inlet. Where a shower head is installed above a bathtub the walls surfaces enclosing the tub need to meet the same requirements as a shower enclosure wall. Where a built-in tub is provided with a shower, the joint where the tub meets an adjacent enclosing wall is required to be waterproof.

diagrams.title: Toilet Paper Dispensers: Recessed (ADA)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The toilet paper dispenser needs to meet a number of clearances that provide for forward reach availability for someone using the toilet, as well as vertical reach. The distances should be measured to the location where the operation occurs, i.e. where the toilet paper comes out of the dispensing device. Clearance to provide for usability of the grab bars also need to be provided. Check also with state or local accessibility requirements for more restrictive scoping, clearance or installation requirements.

ADA Advisory: Section 604.7 Dispensers. If toilet paper dispensers are installed above the side wall grab bar, the outlet of the toilet paper dispenser must be 48 inches maximum above the finish floor and the top of the gripping surface of the grab bar must be 33 inches minimum and 36 inches maximum above the finish floor.

Verify additional requirements of A117.1 (where adopted) or local requirements.

diagrams.title: Toilet Paper Dispenser: Non-Recessed (ADA)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The toilet paper dispenser needs to meet a number of clearances that provide for forward reach availability for someone using the toilet, as well as vertical reach. The distances should be measured to the location where the operation occurs, i.e. where the toilet paper comes out of the dispensing device. Clearance to provide for usability of the grab bars also need to be provided. Check also with state or local accessibility requirements for more restrictive scoping, clearance or installation requirements.

ADA Advisory: Section 604.7 Dispensers. If toilet paper dispensers are installed above the side wall grab bar, the outlet of the toilet paper dispenser must be 48 inches maximum above the finish floor and the top of the gripping surface of the grab bar must be 33 inches minimum and 36 inches maximum above the finish floor.

Verify additional requirements of A117.1 (where adopted) or local requirements.

children.body: The number and type of plumbing fixtures provided in any occupancy shall comply with Chapter 29.
Walls, floors and partitions in toilet and bathrooms shall comply with Sections 1210.2.1 through 1210.2.5.

diagrams.title: Glazing: Wet Surfaces
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Glazing in walls, enclosures or fences containing or facing hot tubs, spas, whirlpools, saunas, steam rooms, bathtubs, showers and indoor or outdoor swimming pools where the bottom exposed edge of the glazing is less than 60 inches measured vertically above any standing or walking surface shall be considered to be a hazardous location. This shall apply to single glazing and all panes in multiple glazing.

Exception: Glazing that is more than 60 inches (1524 mm), measured horizontally and in a straight line, from the water's edge of a bathtub, hot tub, spa, whirlpool or swimming pool.

diagrams.title: Toilet Stall Doors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Toilet door placement allows for usability by a wheelchair user to get in and out of the stall. In addition, a self-closing door is required for toilet compartments as a user with a wheel chair may not be able to reach the out-swinging door and close it after entering the toilet compartment.

diagrams.title: Urinals and Partitions
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Urinals are required to have privacy partitions in accordance with building code 1209.3.2. When such partitions are provided, the clearance between them shall comply with ADA Standards 605. When the space that a wheelchair uses exceeds 24", the area is treated like a deep alcove to be able to give the user room to maneuver backward to get out of the space. See building and plumbing codes for the required numbers of fixtures, and ADA Standards 213.3.3 for the number of urinals required to be accessible. Check also with state or local accessibility requirements for more restrictive scoping, clearance or installation requirements.

diagrams.title: Registers, Grilles and Diffusers - Prohibited Locations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Duct systems are required to provide volume dampers for balancing of the system. The volume dampers are required at each branch duct or at each register, grill or diffuser. All volume dampers required to balance the system must be able to be accessed. In toilet and bathing rooms, registers, grilles and diffusers are not allowed in the floors, the flooring base, or on walls within both 48" of the floor and 24" of a fixture. Floor registers need to be able to resist a 200 lb force applied to a 2" diameter disk applied at the registers weakest location.

children.body: In other than dwelling units, toilet, bathing and shower room floor finish materials shall have a smooth, hard, nonabsorbent surface. The intersections of such floors with walls shall have a smooth, hard, nonabsorbent vertical base that extends upward onto the walls not less than 4 inches (102 mm).

diagrams.title: Bathroom Wall Bases
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A wall base is commonly used in installation of hard surface flooring to cover an expansion gap, cuts when installation of tile or stone has occurred, or in hospitality or commercial settings to provide a sanitary and cleanable edge treatment to prevent damage to the wall.

children.body:
Walls and partitions within 2 feet (610 mm) of service sinks, urinals and water closets shall have a smooth, hard, nonabsorbent surface, to a height of not less than 4 feet (1219 mm) above the floor, and except for structural elements, the materials used in such walls shall be of a type that is not adversely affected by moisture.
Exception: This section does not apply to the following buildings and spaces:
  1. Dwelling units and sleeping units.
  2. Toilet rooms that are not for use by the general public and that have not more than one water closet.
Accessories such as grab bars, towel bars, paper dispensers and soap dishes, provided on or within walls, shall be installed and sealed to protect structural elements from moisture.

diagrams.title: Walls and Partitions in Bathrooms and Toilet Rooms
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Walls within 2' of toilets, urinals and lavatories are required to be finished in a smooth, hard, nonabsorbent surface to 48" minimum above the finished flooring. Shower enclosure walls and walls above tubs with a shower head are required to have a smooth nonabsorbent finish to a height not less than 72" above the drain inlet.

children.body: Walls and partitions within 2 feet (610 mm) measured horizontally from each end of the adult changing table and to a height of not less than 72 inches (1829 mm) above the floor shall have a smooth, hard, nonabsorbent surface, and except for structural elements, the materials used in such walls shall be of a type that is not adversely affected by moisture.
Shower compartments and walls above bathtubs with installed shower heads shall be finished with a smooth, nonabsorbent surface to a height not less than 72 inches (1829 mm) above the drain inlet.

diagrams.title: Bathtubs and Showers: Surfaces and Joints
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Shower enclosure wall surfaces are required to be both smooth and nonabsorbent. The smooth nonabsorbent wall surfaces must extend to a height that is 72" minimum above the shower drain inlet. Where a shower head is installed above a bathtub the walls surfaces enclosing the tub need to meet the same requirements as a shower enclosure wall. Where a built-in tub is provided with a shower, the joint where the tub meets an adjacent enclosing wall is required to be waterproof.

children.body: Built-in tubs with showers shall have waterproof joints between the tub and adjacent wall.

diagrams.title: Bathtubs and Showers: Surfaces and Joints
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Shower enclosure wall surfaces are required to be both smooth and nonabsorbent. The smooth nonabsorbent wall surfaces must extend to a height that is 72" minimum above the shower drain inlet. Where a shower head is installed above a bathtub the walls surfaces enclosing the tub need to meet the same requirements as a shower enclosure wall. Where a built-in tub is provided with a shower, the joint where the tub meets an adjacent enclosing wall is required to be waterproof.

children.body:
Public restrooms shall be visually screened from outside entry or exit doorways to ensure user privacy within the restroom. This provision shall also apply where mirrors would compromise personal privacy. Privacy at water closets and urinals shall be provided in accordance with Sections 1210.3.1 and 1210.3.2.
Exception: Visual screening shall not be required for single-occupant toilet rooms with a lockable door.

Each water closet utilized by the public or employees shall occupy a separate compartment with walls or partitions and a door enclosing the fixtures to ensure privacy.
Exceptions:
  1. Water closet compartments shall not be required in a single-occupant toilet room with a lockable door.
  2. Toilet rooms located in child day care facilities and containing two or more water closets shall be permitted to have one water closet without an enclosing compartment.
  3. This provision is not applicable to toilet areas located within Group I-3 occupancy housing areas.

diagrams.title: Ambulatory and Wheelchair Accessible Water Closets
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Ambulatory accessible toilet compartments provide parallel grab bars and benefit people who use crutches, canes, walkers and similar devices or who need support in sitting or standing. They do not accommodate wheelchairs or scooters and are required in addition to the wheelchair accessible compartment in toilet rooms with six or more toilet compartments or where the combined total of toilets and urinals is six or more. They are sized so that both grab bars are within reach. Grab bars must meet specifications for size, location, and securement.

children.body:
Each urinal utilized by the public or employees shall occupy a separate area with walls or partitions to provide privacy. The walls or partitions shall begin at a height not more than 12 inches (305 mm) from and extend not less than 60 inches (1524 mm) above the finished floor surface. The walls or partitions shall extend from the wall surface at each side of the urinal not less than 18 inches (457 mm) or to a point not less than 6 inches (152 mm) beyond the outermost front lip of the urinal measured from the finished backwall surface, whichever is greater.
Exceptions:
  1. Urinal partitions shall not be required in a single-occupant or family or assisted-use toilet room with a lockable door.
  2. Toilet rooms located in child day care facilities and containing two or more urinals shall be permitted to have one urinal without partitions.

children.body: Where ultraviolet (UV) germicidal irradiation systems are provided, they shall be listed and labeled in accordance with UL 8802 and installed in accordance with their listing and the manufacturer's instruction.
